skill.name: sbom-syft
skill.description: Software Bill of Materials (SBOM) generation using Syft for container images, filesystems, and archives. Detects packages across 28+ ecosystems with multi-format output support (CycloneDX, SPDX, syft-json). Enables vulnerability assessment, license compliance, and supply chain security. Use when: (1) Generating SBOMs for container images or applications, (2) Analyzing software dependencies and packages for vulnerability scanning, (3) Tracking license compliance across dependencies, (4) Integrating SBOM generation into CI/CD for supply chain security, (5) Creating signed SBOM attestations for software provenance.

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill providing SBOM generation guidance using Syft. No executable scripts, no network calls, no file system access, and no external commands. Pure informational content teaching users how to use the Syft CLI tool for supply chain security.

content.user_title: Generate Software Bill of Materials with Syft
content.value_statement: Software supply chain attacks are increasing. Organizations need visibility into their software dependencies. This skill provides step-by-step guidance for generating comprehensive SBOMs using Syft, enabling vulnerability tracking, license compliance, and secure software provenance.
actual_capabilities: Generate SBOMs for container images in CycloneDX, SPDX, and Syft formats
Scan filesystems and source code directories for package dependencies
Create CI/CD pipeline integrations for automated SBOM generation
Analyze SBOM output for vulnerabilities using tools like Grype
Configure signed SBOM attestations for software provenance verification
limitations: Requires Syft CLI tool installation or Docker access for container scanning
Does not perform vulnerability scanning itself, only generates SBOM for downstream tools
Limited to 28+ supported ecosystems, may not detect custom or niche package managers
Cannot scan encrypted or password-protected container images without proper credentials

use_cases.title: CI/CD Pipeline Integration
use_cases.description: Automate SBOM generation in build pipelines for every container release to maintain supply chain transparency

use_cases.title: Vulnerability Tracking
use_cases.description: Generate SBOMs to identify all components in container images and feed data into vulnerability scanners

use_cases.title: License Compliance
use_cases.description: Extract and track license information across all dependencies to ensure regulatory compliance

prompt_templates.title: Pipeline Integration

output_examples.input: Generate a CycloneDX SBOM for alpine:latest
output: Supported by: Grype, Trivy, Dependency Track

best_practices: Generate SBOMs at build time and store them alongside container images for traceability
Use signed attestations (cosign) to verify SBOM integrity and prevent tampering
Integrate SBOM generation into CI/CD pipelines to ensure every release has complete software provenance
anti_patterns: Generating SBOMs only after a security incident instead of proactively at build time
Storing SBOMs in insecure locations where they could be modified by attackers
Using only one SBOM format when tools in your pipeline support multiple formats

faq.question: What SBOM formats does Syft support?
faq.answer: Syft supports CycloneDX JSON/XML, SPDX JSON/tag-value, Syft JSON, GitHub JSON, and custom templates.

faq.question: What programming language ecosystems can Syft analyze?
faq.answer: Syft supports 28+ ecosystems including Python, JavaScript, Go, Java, Ruby, Rust, PHP, .NET, and many more.

faq.question: Can Syft scan running containers?
faq.answer: No, Syft analyzes container images or filesystems. Use Docker save or scan directory contents for running containers.

faq.question: Is SBOM data safe to share?
faq.answer: SBOMs contain package names and versions but may expose internal application details. Share only with trusted parties.

faq.question: Why is my SBOM missing packages?
faq.answer: Try scanning with --scope all-layers or verify package manager files (package.json, go.mod) exist in the image.

faq.question: How does Syft compare to Trivy?
faq.answer: Syft generates SBOMs while Trivy scans for vulnerabilities. They work well together: Syft creates SBOM, Trivy scans it.
